I'm not sure why, but i use arrow functions only for custom methods i write. As for those that are chained to React.Component i use the "normal" method synthax. 
I often declare varibales inside these methods or destructuring  props:
const {myProp} = this.props , 
so i would have to use the return key word anyway.

I think they are normally used when you would need to bind "this" so that kind of creates an autobind for the scope where it is defined. I think having a function is normally better so for standard methods I would define them as standard
You meant "this" context? Because there's no such function that doesn't have scope.
Yes
Arrow function don't have it's own scope so it can scoped to class

Defining those as arrow functions on class properties will not set them on the prototype so I think that's probably not a good idea... you can still use a stateless functional component if you don't want to type "return" though.
well, you could use CoffeeScript for that... but no thanks :p
Or can just use Ruby for your back end stuff.
I miss Ruby where the last line in a method is always returned
I don't like the class field syntax. Prefer explicit bind wherever appropriate.

Don't use class property syntax for lifecycle methods (render, componentDidMount, etc). I THINK doing so will cause scoping issues, but I may be wrong. Only use it for your own methods.

Class properties are great in React, because you don't have to worry about binding your methods when using them in events. Using syntax like "onClick={this.myAction.bind(this)}" should be avoided whenever possible anyway, as it could lead to lots of unnecessary re-rendering.

If I'm passing a function outside of the original context, I use a property declaration to get an easy bind.
Method declarations for everything else. Doing this, at glance, I can see which functions the children have access to.

data.message: What is the best database for large e-commerce websites and why?
data.story: Dhaneshwar Patidar created a poll in ReactJS.

data.message: I really think that it depends on the data model of the application, and not entirely on the business domain. Also, it is quite possible to use more than one kind, if that is something you can benefit from.
There is no one best, I think it depends mostly on what you enjoy using most. It's also common to use multiple technologies.

Some of them might have, but I do have to ask, Do you think that mongo's success is due to it's popularity, or vice versa? Because document databases, such as mongo, offer a clear advantages over relational ones- in some use cases. (Mongo simply offers the richest query options available)
If there were no advantages I guess it wouldn't exist. However, my comment was more an amusing reflection than anything else
Although, personally I find mongoDB lots cooler than sql
Lol, lack of advantages has maintained the existence of many things
tries to do a complex aggregation operation in mongodb..... cry
I think everyone who klicked mongoDB might have done it because it's more cool than sql
Mongo provides a schema free structure and I think that's the only good reason. It's flexible, can be scaled to any extent.
not to mention transaction/consistency problems....
People are probably just tagging Mongo here to seem hip
Mongodb for ecommerce ? Sounds like denormalization hell with complex product structure, reviews, orders, comments etc
Depends on the use case
Postgres because JSON + SQL
Seems like the exact use case for what you would never use mongo
mongodb for ecommerce ?? ...
Lol mongo???
Check this http://cryto.net/~joepie91/blog/2015/07/19/why-you-should-never-ever-ever-use-mongodb/

What a ridiculous article. Geez. “No valid use case for Mongo”? I mean, MongoDB isn’t perfect.. and has issues when storing large arrays embedded in a document. But you CAN have a pseudo-relational model in MongoDB, which becomes really easy to work with when used in conjunction with GraphQL.

Pick the right tool for the job. It won’t always be a particular solution.
Saad Abbasi any suggestions? I think Mongo is better with flexible structure.
In our experience MongoDB is by far the least suitable database for a *large e-commerce* site. I'm surprised by the amount of votes it got and seriously question the motivation for those votes

Hey guys. I am quite dissatisfied with Redux and Redux thunk at how it handles side effects.

Did anyone use any other alternative in production? I am looking for recommendations.

I am currently looking at RxJS but I read it can get quite hard to track what is going on later on.

The problem is my async action creators have to sometimes call 5 APIs in a row and break the chain or go to another sequence of API calls if something doesn't succeed in between.

Basically that means a bunch of promises with if else type of scenarios and inbetween actions being dispatched to give feedback to the view.
Oh nice. Can I skip sagas and go to RxJS? :D I want to skip levelling up and see the end game content lol.
Sure but sagas are fine if you are new to react. They are actually pretty complicated. The main difference is that Rxjs people prefer functional programming.
Here is a WIP boilerplate for redux with redux-saga. based on ducking: https://github.com/Evanion/Saints-Kernel
i have a version that is refactored to be cross platform, and not bound to React .. but it's on my work computer.
It looks to place application logic within components.  Why not redux-thunk instead?  The redux document makes note of this issue with thunk as a solution.
redux-saga is completely outisde the ract componets. you just bind the actions and store from redux in your component props the same as with thunks.

You call dispatch from components, components shouldn't have access to dispatch.  That's application logic.

At least that's what the documentation shows.
here is an example of a component that calls a saga to register a user: https://gitlab.com/saints-gaming/website/blob/master/src/partials/Register/index.js

It is basically redux -> redux thunk -> sagas -> rxjs (from left to right as you level up)

https://github.com/redux-saga/redux-saga
Sagas have worked great for me.
Rxjs is a library for reactive programming ported to JS. If you want to compare with Redux saga, you have to use Redux Observable which is built on top of RxJs
go for redux-observable.
Mobx state tree.
Sometimes a middleware can solve a lot of problems
Take a look at redux-thunk for async dispatches within actions.  I'm also not a fan of RxJS, so I have some bias.   But I will say, RxJS works great with Angular patterns.

data.message:
for REST API's - fetch(), the reason is it's native on most browsers and I don't need to install another dependency on my app

for GraphQL endpoints - Apollo React, easy to use, self-documenting API
why don't you use axios with next? axios is isomorphic itself...
This makes me trouble with the Absolut url in the getInitialProps() function
what do you mean exactly?
I did not check it thoroughly, but in get request with axios it got an error: "only absolute urls are supported". see here: https://github.com/zeit/next.js/issues/2153
axios for client side, isomorphic-fetch for SSR (like next.js)

I used to be pro-fetch() and anti-Axios for web since fetch() is native, but fetch error handling is truly lacking as it still will not trigger the catch block in many error cases. Also, it's nice to not have to run .json() on returned data, but that is not so important. I prefer fetch() for React Native projects though, as Axios version-to-version compatibility with React Native is not as solid as it is for React-DOM
i think Axios is also a good library
I suggest Axios - only because even after 2 years of fetch working group discussions, you STILL CAN'T ABORT A FETCH!   And then there's lack of tracking upload/download progress.

Just want to make sure I understand JWT authentication flow:

1. React sends user login info to the server
2. The server creates a token and sends it back (doesn't store in db!)
3. React receives the token and stores it in localStorage or whatever
4. On each subsequent API call React retrieves the token and sends it to the server
5. The server verifies the token, checks expiration and sends back appropriate response.
6. React acts on the response received.
cool guy! we have to save this token to db and then when user change password we can remove this token and get user have to re-login :)
Tiến Văn Trần
Oh ok, I understand, that's a good point! Thanks!

There are missinformation on how jwt should work. JWT was created to be stateless so... if we store the token on a db we are breaking one of the main principes of the jwt philosophy. In any case, yes, you can store it on a db to wether check pw change, banning or whatever you want.
Carlos Nuñez Tomeo Thats a good point about being stateless

2. The server creates a token and sends it back (doesn't store in db!)
This's important. If you want to reset all token when you changed password, so you need store token db to check token expired without expired in JWT
Thanks! So you are saying I don't have store the token in the database?

JWT tokens shouldn't contain any sensitive information in the payload. The server verifies the signature of the token and you can use the payload to add not sensitive info about the user like the info help you to handle authorization or password changing. you can store a random string with the user and change it when the user change his password and by adding this attribute to the token payload you can verify if the token expired or not. I think there are more approaches to handle password change but  remember that token payload must not contain any  sensitive information.

you are right, but in case of password change it always verifies with password and username by user data for each request comes to server, so you don't need to be worry about password and jwt expiration on password change.
yeah if you want to implement token revocation logic, then the token needs to be stored on the db, otherwise not

well .. to revoke tokens on password change, just have 2 tokens... the first one have a short lifetime (1-3 hours) and the second token is a 'refresh token' that salts the secret with the users password hash. That way, if the password changes, the token won't be refreshed when the first token expires.

This way, you still don't need to hit the db every time to validate against a user object, or stored token. and you will only hit the db when the first token expires every 1-3 hours depending on your setting. Ben Awad uses it nicely in his slack clone tutorial on YT: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sK9SjEjlz6U&list=PLN3n1USn4xlkdRlq3VZ1sT6SGW0-yajjL&index=12
that would still require you to call the db on every request, negating a major advantage of using JWTs
for blacklisting, i think we need to have some information about token. and to get that information, we nedd to have db. is there any other way for blacklisting tokens?

You are right, however my points was more so about storing and maintaining a token in a DB, not limiting queries. Blacklisting or checking the password change date is fairly inexpensive compared to that. I'd still assume that most use cases where JWT is used for authentication will query the user and/or additional resources when a request hits the server.

well check the 'log out of all devices' feature on netflix .. they have a 24 hour timeout and are basically using a similar solution to a refresh token .. basically a main session token with a 24 hour TTL and a secondary token used to refresh that is signed with a user specific secret. 

when you call the 'log out of all devices' feature they simply change the user specific secret.
not really... since the JWT token contains the main user information needed for most requests (id, ev policies etc)... that way you don't need to call the db for 90%+ of all requests
an extra roundtrip to the db is a fairly large amount of time to add on a request, it easily adds 10-20% extra time to a request.

yeah i think maintaining the user specific secret and upon password change or log out of all devices, change that secret to invalidate all the previous tokens is much better. Thank you Mikael Pettersson.
would you consider storing user email in the token bad security practice?

yes, since the first two sections of the token is decodable (base64 encoded), you shouldn't store confidential information in them .. and the larger you make the token, the easier they are to reverse engineer

Mikael Pettersson I definitely agree, that's a great solution, however you still need to compare the user specific secret which needs to be stored somewhere, with the only difference being that you compare it every X hours. I don't disagree that it may be better.

edit: I got it a little mixed up in this conversation, you were not the one talking about no db use case.

 Shrawan Lakhe Not sure if increased payload size on users JWT is more efficient and maintains the security aspect versus a simple query for a single change ? I guess it depends on the kind of user information you need and how you are storing/retrieving the data on requests.

well when you need to refresh the token, you will have to check the user object in your datastore, it's the only way to get a secure piece of information.

you can check my implementation based on Ben Awads here: https://github.com/Evanion/GraphQL-server/blob/master/src/middleware/Authorization/verifyToken.js

balance your need for how quickly a token deprecation should take effect, with how much load you put on your database.

if you need quick invalidation of tokens, lower the TTL of your authentication token. That will increase the load on the database, as the token will get refreshed more often. If it's more important that you limit the load on your database, increase the TTL on the token to lower the frequency of token refresh.

If you need to revoke token on password change just check by tokens expiration date and password change date or blacklist the token used for password change. No need to overcomplicate, one of the advantages of JWT is that you don't have to store and maintain it on the server side.
This guide should answer some of those questions: https://auth0.com/blog/cookies-vs-tokens-definitive-guide/
Yeah I have read their stance on tokens as well as many other articles on this topic.
check the responses to Szymon Majdak comment above for a more in depth discussion about revocation.
Thanks. I am going to read it. There seems to be a heated debate.

Oh yeah. That is how it works. Also, the server has to implement a way to revoke jwt tokens in case an account gets hacked. Expiry date is a nice start but black listing is still required if you want best security practices. Facebook does not use JWT tokens btw. It is using cookies. Maybe it is because of legacy of their ways of doing things or... Maybe it is just better from security perspective.
just make sure you have a means to revoke a token and use ssl to prevent mitm attacks to a certain degree.
token expiration is no different than session expiration, and you handle it the same way.
And another important part is how to automatically renew the token. In your case user will be logged out even if he/she is active in the moment, but token expired.

Hi everyone, just wanted to share my latest project with you today.

Manta is a flexible invoicing desktop app that allows you to quickly make beautiful invoices without the need of using design software like Photoshop, InDesign or Sketch. 

It's geared toward people who need to make invoices from time to time such as freelance designers, developers, photographers or writers ...

Main features:
* 🏗 Flexible form.
* 🎨 Custom designed templates which can be customized further to match your brand's style.
* 📊 Export to PDF for printing or email.
* 💯  Totally free.

If you're interested in the source code, feel free to take a look here: https://github.com/hql287/Manta.

Hope you will find this useful. 
Feedbacks, ideas and suggestions are always welcomed.

Enjoy your weekend! :)

data.message: Planning to use JWT Web Tokens for authentication for my React app. Not sure what should go in the payload. I authenticate users by their email. If I include email, token expiry and creation would that be fine?
Following...
Jwt? U only need the token in your payload. Usually it would be stored on localstorage for easy access for your http client(axios, and etc).
Thanks. That's a good idea to have an id only. I think I'll do that.

Me, i just included the id and expiration date. But on some they can include the whole user information requires since you will have sessionless. It depend on how many  information you need from the token.
Thanks!
Yah dont store password or email in there. jwt is not encrypted. Just insensitive info

Yeah depends if you want to
 show insensitive  user profile 
information directly from the token data then you can include basic information. Otherwise include the id in the token and use that I'd to fetch user detail . since its stored on the local storage, you can decode the token and get user info
Follow
Thanks, will look into that. What problems did you run into when implementing JWT?
You can't really invalidate tokens,  not easily anyway. If you keep a blacklist or whitelist you're essentially reimplementing your own version of sessions...
Gan Wei Jian Thanks!
I did the mistake of implementing JWT, but turns out what I actually want is just simple sessions. Please find out more about stateless authentication before committing to JWT :)
Email or Id, usually good for most cases 👌

Stupid concept? Really? You have to have a look at mobx-state-tree then.
#burn
Mobx is a no brainer, while Redux is like UNIX, it is simple, it just needs a genius to understands it's simplicity.
MobX is not a no-brainer. It is not even simple and contains a lot of subtle traps. https://mobx.js.org/best/pitfalls.html.
On the other side, Redux is too verbose and is not consistent for dealing with side effects (reducers cannot contain side effects). Although it was solved by redux-loop.

There is another state management library which uses the brain in the proper way. ;) It uses a very readable, DECLARATIVE, consistent API for both, synch and async actions. It has the best debugger from all those libs. Welcome to Cerebral. ;)
Fear?? It’s not fear - it is called “having a brain”. You need to be an idiot to use redux. Such an ugly and stupid concept. Better use mobx if you need a state manager...

From the annals of reddit:
In response to the position : "If you use LMGTFY you're an asshole"
"
It depends on the kind of question being asked. If it's something that has to do with nuance or expertise, or is asking for some general opinion relevant to the context you're currently in, yes the person is an asshole who doesn't know what LMGTFY is for.
But if it's a question that is a simple, contained bit of entirely fact-based information, in my opinion LMGTFY is called for. Think about this: if somebody handed you a dictionary and asked you to look up "extemporaneous" for them, you'd probably ask "Ok, but why can't you do it?"
LMGTFY is somebody asking, "Why can't you do it?"
"
https://www.reddit.com/r/Negareddit/comments/3zt210/if_you_use_lmgtfy_youre_an_asshole/?st=jaot1vea&sh=f7c0c267
